page.pageNote: The reading of John Brown's letters at a Philadelphia meeting; general and political news; Facts and Fancies.
Story of a robbery with a happy ending; advertisements.

div.head: The Glasgow Herald
div.summary: A thanks to James Sharp, Esq., for sending two copies of the Herald, printed at Glasgow Scotland, while he is in Europe. The editors note the similarity between the Repository and its Scottish cousin paper.

div.head: True Aim Of A Republic.
div.summary: The Repository describes how, in a Republic, all men have equal opportunity to happiness, but that in the South, the welfare of only a few (the wealthy slaveholders) are being considered.

div.head: The Execution Of Brown
div.summary: A lengthy description of John Brown's execution, and of his meeting with his wife beforehand. An interesting point-- Brown accused Cook of misrepresenting the situation at Harper's Ferry--that the slaves there were Not ripe for insurrection, as Cook had led him to believe.

div.head: Cook's Confession
div.summary: Cook's description of the events leading up to and including the insurrection at Harper's Ferry. There is mention of Chambersburg's brief role as a place from which guns and other weapons were shipped.

div.head: On Strike

transcript.p: --We are sorry to learn that the hands heretofore working on the Franklin Railroad have discontinued their work. The contractor deemed it his duty to reduce their wages, during the short days, from one dollar to ninety cents per day--which is the cause of the strike.

div.summary: The hands working on the Franklin Railroad have stopped working due to a reduction in pay (from a $1.00 to $.90) on the short days.

div.head: Robbery
div.excerpt: "The burglars then robbed the Store of some $20 or $25 in money, four pairs of boots and some other articles."

transcript.p: --The Store of Mr. Rob't Black, of Greenwood, this county, was burglariously entered on Friday night last, the 2d. inst., by some person ore persons unknown. An entrance was effected by boring a panel out of the front door. The burglars then robbed the Store of some $20 or $25 in money, four pairs of boots and some other articles.--

div.summary: The store of Robert Black, in Greenwood, was robbed on Dec. 2nd. The thief or thieves bore out a panel in the door, and stole $20-25 and 4 pairs of boots and other articles.

div.head: The First Annual Fair Of The Farmers And Mechanics Industrial Association Of Franklin County, Pa.

page.pageNote: Continuation of Cook's confession; Advertisements; market reports.

div.head: Scraps Of Unwritten History
div.summary: An article that describes a number of Democrats (Sumner, Burlingame, Broderick, to name a few) who were bullied, attacked or censured by members of their own party for going against the general Democrat stance or locofoco leaders.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On Dec. 1st, at the home of the bride's uncle, Peter Alrich, Esq., near Wilmington, Del., Rev. William Akeman married Josiah W. fletcher, Esq., of Chambersburg, to Mary Virginia Peach, of Wilmington Del. On Dec. 1st, Rev. S. McHenry married John R. Eberly, of the vincinity of Chambersburg, to Elizabeth, daughter of Jacob Dietrich, Esq., of Hamilton twp. On Dec. 1st, at the White Swan Hotel, in Chambersburg, Rev. Samuel Philips married Alexander Willhide to Elizabeth Scott, both of Mt. Hope, Franklin Co.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On Nov. 27th, near Chambersburg, Andrew, youngest son of Andrew J. McNair, died at age 7 months and 19 days.

page.pageNote: Book Table; advertisements; real estate sales.
